abstract:
This method explains how to extract DNA from environmental water samples that have undergone a filtration process using a phenol-chloroform approach. The necessity of this technique arises due to the presence of environmental DNA (eDNA) in water samples, which can provide valuable information about the organisms present in an ecosystem.

Originally described by Renshaw et al. (2015), this method was modified by Kim Parsons from National Forestry and Fisheries Science Center (NWFSC). The phenol-chloroform approach involves using a mixture of phenol and chloroform to separate the DNA from other contaminants in the sample.

The reason for using this technique lies in the challenge of effectively extracting high-quality DNA from eDNA samples, which can be complex due to the presence of various substances that may interfere with downstream applications, such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or sequencing.

By employing a room temperature preservation step prior to DNA extraction, this method enhances the stability and integrity of eDNA samples, ensuring a successful subsequent DNA extraction process. The phenol-chloroform approach effectively separates the desired DNA from unwanted substances by exploiting their differences in density. Thus, it provides a critical step towards obtaining pure and high-quality DNA for further analysis.

description:
This text describes a DNA extraction method from filtered environmental DNA (eDNA) samples using a phenol-chloroform approach. The process begins with the modification of an existing method by Kim Parsons from NWFSC, as outlined in Renshaw et al. (2015).

The initial step involves preserving eDNA samples at room temperature prior to extraction. Next, the DNA is extracted utilizing a phenol-chloroform-isoamyl alcohol solution. The method proceeds with the following steps:

1. Thaw the filtered eDNA samples on ice and mix them well before starting the procedure.
2. Add an equal volume of phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol (25:24:1) to each tube, ensuring that the tubes are securely capped before mixing by inversion for approximately 1 minute.
3. Centrifuge the mixtures at 12000 x g for 10 minutes at room temperature to separate the phases.
4. Transfer the upper aqueous layer to a new tube carefully, avoiding transferring any phenol or interphase material.
5. Repeat steps 2 through 4 once more.
6. Add an equal volume of chloroform:isoamyl alcohol (24:1) to the upper layer and mix gently by inversion for about 30 seconds before centrifuging at 12000 x g for 5 minutes at room temperature.
7. Transfer the upper aqueous layer to a new tube once more, being careful not to include any interphase material or phenol.
8. Precipitate the DNA by adding an appropriate amount of carrier agent (such as glycogen or sodium acetate) and 2.5 volumes of absolute ethanol to each tube. Mix well by inversion.
9. Incubate the tubes at -20°C for at least 1 hour, or overnight if preferred.
10. Centrifuge the tubes at 4°C for 30 minutes at maximum speed (approximately 15,000 rpm) to pellet the DNA. Carefully remove and discard the supernatant.
11. Wash the DNA pellets by adding 70% ethanol and centrifuging the tubes at 4°C for 5 minutes at maximum speed. Carefully decant the ethanol and allow the pellets to air-dry or use a desiccator.
12. Dissolve the DNA in an appropriate volume of sterile water, TE buffer, or another suitable elution buffer. The concentration can be adjusted as needed for downstream applications.
13. Store the DNA extracts at 4°C or -20°C until further use.

This phenol-chloroform method efficiently extracts high-quality DNA from eDNA samples, ensuring successful downstream applications such as PCR or sequencing.
